Up Against the Wall Motherfucker, often shortened as The Motherfuckers or UAW, was a radical activist group in New York City during the 1960s. The group was formed in 1967 by a collective of artists, activists, and musicians, including Ben Morea, Jano, and Aldo Tambellini. They were known for their anti-establishment and anti-war views, as well as their use of provocative and often humorous tactics to challenge societal norms.

The Motherfuckers were a key part of the city's counterculture movement, and their activities included organizing protests, creating street art, and publishing an underground newspaper called "Black Mask." They also ran a free store in the East Village, where people could come to exchange goods and services without using money.

The group's name was inspired by a poem by Amiri Baraka, and it was meant to be a provocative challenge to mainstream culture. The Motherfuckers were not afraid to push boundaries and challenge authority, and their activities often put them at odds with the police and other establishment figures. Despite this, they played an important role in shaping the city's counterculture movement and inspiring future generations of activists and artists.

We had different interests, values, and priorities, and it seemed that our differences had finally come to a head. Holding onto resentment and anger would only consume me, and I didn't want to give my former friend that power. Instead, I chose to focus on nurturing the positive relationships in my life and surrounding myself with people who uplifted and supported me. It wasn't easy, but it was a necessary step towards healing and growth.”
